### “Good Is Hard”: Lobotomy, Fritz Haber, and Misapplied Innovation
I once gave a talk called “Good is Hard,” highlighting two innovators. One loved his patients so much he pioneered the lobotomy—once considered a last resort for severe cases. But others then monetized and scaled it for profit, leading to tragedy.

Fritz Haber, seeking acceptance in Germany as a Jewish scientist, helped fix nitrogen from the air—originally so Germany could make bombs. This invention also fed the world by creating cheap fertilizers. Yet overuse has led to polluted waters and dead zones.

In both cases, the original impulse might have been love or necessity, but efficiency and profit took over. The lesson is that if we innovate with only rational efficiency and ignore our deeper faculty of beauty, we risk causing enormous harm.

### Gratitude, Entitlement, and Daily Practice
A gratitude practice can help, but not if we remain stuck in entitlement—this idea that “I deserve this.” Entitlement is the opposite of gratitude because it’s rooted in the mind that says, “I did this” rather than “I saw and responded.” If we examine our to-do lists, we can see which items are grounded in deeper truth and which are just habits or obligations we never question.
